definition: The working relationship between author and editor involving communication, negotiation, and shared commitment to improving the work

positive_examples: Author-editor collaboration established shared goals and boundaries before the edit began.
The collaborative relationship allowed for frank discussion of the manuscript's weaknesses.
Effective author-editor collaboration respects the author's ownership while leveraging editor expertise.
The collaboration evolved as trust built through successive revision rounds.
Author-editor collaboration established that certain stylistic choices were non-negotiable before editing began.
negative_examples: The author and editor worked together.
training_hints.disambiguation: Structured professional collaboration, not mere interaction
